meanings.definition: Teach (a person or group) to accept a set of beliefs uncritically.
meanings.sent1: The teacher indoctrinated the students with the idea that hard work always pays off.
meanings.sent2: The cult leader indoctrinated his followers to believe he was a divine being.
meanings.sent3: The children were indoctrinated into thinking that eating vegetables would give them superpowers.
meanings.sent4: The advertisement indoctrinated consumers to believe their product was the key to happiness.
meanings.sent5: The propaganda film indoctrinated the audience with messages of fear and control.

meanings.definition: Instruct in a doctrine, principle, ideology, etc., especially to imbue with a specific partisan or biased belief or point of view.
meanings.sent1: The political party indoctrinated its members with extreme views on immigration.
meanings.sent2: The extremist group indoctrinated new recruits with hatred towards other religions.
meanings.sent3: The chef jokingly indoctrinated his sous-chefs to believe that adding extra salt would make the food taste better.
meanings.sent4: The fashion magazine indoctrinated young readers with the idea that beauty is only skin deep.
meanings.sent5: The self-help guru indoctrinated his followers with the belief that positivity attracts success.
